review_title: University is being run into the ground
job_title: Representative in Saint Louis, MO

Pay is far below the national average, no staff bonuses for 5+ years, but senior management have been receiving raises every year. Poor managing of funds. Average 9 hour workdays.

job_title: Manager in Webster Groves, St. Louis, MO
pros: Love working in Higher Education, the people and students are great.

job_title: Public Safety Officer in Webster Groves, St. Louis, MO
pros: Great team and fun environment. Open work assignments allow for a lot of self driven work.
cons:
Poor executive leadership who is out of touch with current environment.  No accountability for financial and programming mistakes.

Terrible pay, no raises, furloughs, little to no opportunity for advancement.

University wants officers to confront unknown subjects, yet refuses to allow officers to carry any protective devices.

job_title: Office Administrator in Saint Louis, MO

review_title: Stuck in "The Webster Way" of doing business.
job_title: IT Support in Saint Louis, MO
pros:
Outstanding benefit package.
Great leave and personal time off.
Great students.
Extremely dedicated faculty.
Outstanding curriculum and educational experience.
cons: Graduates become staff or faculty. With no other work experience to reference there is an entrenched status quo. If you have a difference of view you are shunned and not considered a team player.  I was told by several mangers that "we should all say the same thing to anyone that make an inquire about services" even if it is not correct. You must drink the cup of poisoned Kool-aide they offer you if you are to prosper and advance. The herd mentality is stiffing. Most of the IT management are incapable of understanding the the words of Thomas Jefferson "Differences in opinions leads to inquires and inquires lead to enlightenment."

job_title: Academic Systems Support in Saint Louis, MO
pros:
Work/Life balance is above average

cons:
Poor management
Low pay with no potential for increases in the foreseeable future

job_title: Associate Professor in Webster Groves, MO
pros: Faculty and Staff are supportive of each other, good working atmosphere
cons: lower pay for adjuncts in Midwest

job_title: Chief Information Officer (CIO) in Saint Louis, MO
pros: benefits, travel, innovation, work environment
cons: none none none none none

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Flexible schedule, good work / life balance, great benefits like their employer contribution to the 403b plan and most jobs are pretty secure no matter what you do; mostly Webster is full of good people - they're just not given the opportunity to innovate and succeed
cons: Current management lacks courage to make the hard, necessary, strategic decisions for any higher ed institution to succeed in the 21st century; the academic affairs division is the biggest and functions most like a silo, stifling innovation; there have been some pockets of leaders trying to do right by their people, but mostly it's stuck in a rut of hierarchy and bureaucracy

job_title: Department Assistant in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Good benefits and opportunity to take classes
cons: very little pay and no recognition

review_title: Webster is a crap shoot depending on what area of the University you work in.
job_title: Administrative Assistant in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Excellent retirement benefits - up to 6% employee contribution matched up to 9.5% from Webster.  Good work-life balance, depending on what area you work in and your supervisor.  Good healthcare coverage as well.  Some areas of the university offer a somewhat flexible work schedule, but not all.
cons: No advancement opportunities for staff.  Poor employee morale and recent employee turnover.  Upper management has created a climate that makes employees feel that the management can't/doesn't trust them.  Pay is already on the low end and raises over the past few years have been marginal at best.  Lack of clear, concise communication from leadership.  Policy changes aren't widely disseminated throughout the organization.

job_title: Coordinator in Saint Louis, MO
pros: The tuition remission benefits are extremely valuable if you, your children or your spouse are wanting to attend university now or soon. Webster also has a great work/life balance with excellent vacation benefits.
cons:
It is difficult to inspire tenured faculty to respect and recognize the needs of the staff who are there to help them. It creates problems for the staff who have a job to do, but they can't because faculty won't give them what is needed in a timely manner. 
Faculty are put into supervisory roles without any training. So many of them are really poor supervisors with little to no organizational skills or understanding of how to deal with direct reports.

job_title: Assistant Professor, Adjunct/Part Time in Jacksonville, FL
pros: Working with non-traditional students who really want to learn.  Our smaller campus gets a close community feel with strong support system of a large brick and mortar university.  Professors who are experts in their respective fields and students who bring a lot of personal and professional experience to the classroom.
cons: Not everyone loves classes that are 4 hours long in the evening and 8 hours long on Sat, but the class times are great to accommodate around most work and family schedules.  As part time faculty, there is no place for promotion (no full-time faculty on this campus) and it would be wonderful to have full-time teaching and/or administrative opportunities.

review_title: No clarity,  Real information like pulling teeth
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Louis, MO
pros: The people. The atmosphere. Good benefits and great matching retirement benefit.  Free tuition for dependent.  Free classes for employees.
cons: We never get told the truth about what's happening with budgets cuts and layoffs.  Had layoffs in 2015 but knew nothing about any other departments also having the same. Never new how much the deficit was till this year finally.  No raises.  Mid range pay.   Mandatory furlough day now in place. One day.

review_title: Great place with amazing potential but serious leadership issues
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Good benefits, interesting and complex place, a lot of great people work there.  A vision that can be very inspiring.
cons: dysfunctional and top-heavy leadership structure.  Financial issues due to over-extension of resources.  Competency will be rewarded with more work and no more pay.

job_title: Associate Professor in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Summers off for faculty. Great faculty-staff connections for support and idea generation.
cons: Low pay for faculty and staff. No cost of living increase in the 9 years I've been there. Little advancement support. Expectation is to work 24 hours a day on projects that aren't in you job description because the university doesn't want to spend the money to hire someone to do it.

job_title: Information Technology in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Webster University is a great place to work, especially if you are continuing your undergraduate/graduate degree!  Benefits are provided immediately and extend to family members and/or your spouse.  Recognition of domestic partnership along with their diversity visibility initiatives make for a comfortable work environment.
cons: Your best mode of transportation will possibly be to either carpool or try transit.  Parking is sparse until the new plans for restructuring the main campus grounds are set into place.

review_title: It's becoming about the numbers now
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Louis, MO
pros:
It's a great educational institution as a whole.  The instructors all know their respective industries and teach it to their students.  They are also about their students.

Benefits are nice.

Working here has allowed me to get my masters and then some.
cons:
St. Louis doesn't care about the employees outside of St. Louis.  Last year they cut the extended campus' ability to take the staff out for a Christmas lunch, however, St. Louis threw an expensive Gala for their staff.  Let me rephrase that, they told the extended campuses that we could not have a Christmas anything.  ---They, however, did have a huge Gala that was represented on Facebook.  No one in St. -Louis knew/knows about it.

Pay is below the state standards.

Benefits are starting to decrease in order to keep more of that money in St. Louis.

Our technology is becoming antiquated.  Individual campuses are using their budget to get better equipment.

The heads that steer this vehicle have decided that having many systems that do not work well with each other or even as a standalone work better and more efficient that one or two systems that communicate with each other and allow for efficiency and effectiveness.  

The culture and values at Webster, St. Louis have shifted and no one there cares about those extended campuses anymore.

I have not received a raise in 3 years!  We have been told that we have to obtain an excellent rating, however, they also tell us that we cannot receive one because no one deserves one.

job_title: Office Assistant in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Fast environment that tends to pickup during the start and end of enrollment sessions. The biggest upside to this position is getting tuition remission for education. I was able to earn multiple degrees while working here. Getting to interact with students and faculty is a great way to network and mingle with the community. Long winter break while campus is closed for Christmas.
cons: Base salary is low and benefits are high. People simply don't get paid enough to worry about the details at Webster.

job_title: Core Faculty | Academic Advisor in Charleston, SC
pros: Prior to June 2014 the Charleston Metro Campus was a great place to work with an administration that cared about their students.
cons: Beginning June 2014 the Administration considered the students walking dollar signs without concern for their Academic needs.  Also, the uneducated support staff treated the students & adjunct faculty with disrespect.  Finally, the pay is not commensurate with employee credentials nor does it reflect the reality of the cost of living in the Charleston Metro Area which, unlike most of SC,  is an expensive place to live.

job_title: Graduate Student Worker in Webster Groves, St. Louis, MO
pros: Managerial staff very supportive.  Faculty trying hard to support grad students.  This is a great place to learn to deal with bureaucracy and to develop professional relationships.  You learn how to become a colleague and a leader.
cons: Some of the administrative staff and financial office staff take their jobs for granted--they act like we are supposed to accept whatever level of work they believe is appropriate.

job_title: Manager in Webster Groves, St. Louis, MO
pros: Faculty and staff are hard working and easy to get along with
cons: Lack of raises for years, giving up a days pay required, even though the president and bursar received bonuses, impossible work loads to handle, a lot of pressure daily due to decreased personnel due to budget cuts.

review_title: One of the best places to work!  I think it is even rated one of the best colleges to work for in the U.S.
job_title: Adjunct Professor in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Collaboration, innovation, and good leadership .    Easy to work with the student population.  The faculty support is incredible.   The faculty development resources on line are very helpful and accessible.   Great website to support the faculty
cons: maybe need a 24 hour IT help desk

job_title: Department Associate in Orlando, FL
pros: I loved my team, the benefits are great and the pto/sick days given are very generous. I loved having the week off for Xmas and NYE.
cons: Some of the upper management/directors forget that this is a school and their compassion/feelings towards students can be a little misguided. But then again some people give students too much.

job_title: in Saint Louis, MO
pros: The students and fellow employees make it a rewarding place of employment.  Quaint campus in a nice location (although most of the older buildings/residences providing the character either have been or are slated to be torn down to provide space for larger facilities).
cons: Salaries lag behind industry, poor management and lack of communication.  Like most universities lack of parking is a chronic problem.

job_title: Public Safety Officer in Saint Louis, MO
pros:
-people within departments are frendly and easy to work with
-low stress
-great benefits
-fun environment
cons:
-President and provovost receive yearly incentive based bonuses despite poor performances
-7 years straight years in the red, current administration has been there ...7years
-very uncompetitive pay
-resistance to change
-not in touch with current social and economic climates (in terms of security)
-poor resources management 
-little to no upward mobility

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Webster Groves, St. Louis, MO
pros: Flexible scheduling if needed, FREE college, laid back environment. Decent campus dining. Most of the mid level managers are pretty decent.
cons: The upper administration gets yearly pay raises and bonuses, yet projections and enrollment are down every year for the last 4 years. Meanwhile the day to day employees struggle to survive.

review_title: It isn't the place it used to be
job_title: Associate Professor in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Faculty and staff are generally amazing people and are fantastic to work with.
cons: The administration cares more about lining their pockets than doing what's good for the university or its people (faculty and staff). Promotions are rare; raises are rarer. Keeping up with the cost of living is impossible.

review_title: Great place to be a part of
job_title: Admissions Representative in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Great diverse atmosphere of people who are all very courteous and caring. No one seems to feel uncomfortable amongst their colleagues.
cons: Communication between departments can be frustrating due to inconsistencies in protocol between them. A more streamlined, singular way of doing things may make things easier.

job_title: Adjunct Professor in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Flexibility of office hours, colleagues, caliber of students, international focus, select own text for courses, value professional real world experience and support team.
cons: Salary schedule, same senior leaders at the top until recently, and if you step away from teaching for awhile you start all over on the salary schedule and need to provide more opportunity for adjunct faculty to interact.

review_title: Mostly, it's a pretty good place to work.
job_title: in Saint Louis, MO
pros: The staff, students, teachers, chances for advancement and retirement package are pretty good,  even when you compare to other schools.
cons: The low teacher and staff salaries and constant parking problems are a grind, all the time. It's  kind of demoralizing.

review_title: Excellent benefits, great opportunity for advancement

pros:
- Tuition Remission for employee and family

job_title: Bonded Locksmith/Maintenance II in Webster Groves, St. Louis, MO

job_title: Midi Room Audio Engineer in Saint Louis, MO

Get to work with cool gear and get paid.
Laid back for the most part.
Flexible hours
Good pay 
Fun people to work with and you meet a bunch of peeps in your field of study

Can get a bit boring at times
Hours sometimes are late ones

review_title: Low barrier to tenure, but also low pay
job_title: Associate Professor in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Low barrier to tenure, 9 month contract, ability to travel to other campuses
cons: Faculty are expected to do their job, as well as the jobs of every staff member that's left due to low pay and lack of respect. Administration is out of touch with students, faculty and the mission of higher education.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Brentwood, MO
pros: Flexible class times, great class sizes, flexibility of the department to teach the class.  The other adjunct professors can be very helpful.
cons: There is not enough of a commitment to the adjuncts.  This has been better over the last few years, but would like to see more commitment.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Faculty and staff are great to work with on a daily basis.  Very accommodating with requested time off and the benefits are great.
cons: Declining enrollment is becoming an issue.  Department is understaffed due to not being able to hire vacant positions putting a strain on everyone.  There is no room for professional advancement within the university.

job_title: in Saint Louis, MO
pros: The benefits package: healthcare, access to the library and gym facilities, and free education, are all top notch. General atmosphere is relaxed friendly.
cons: As with any higher educational institution, get used to internal politics, stubborn tenured professors, and organizations slow to change.

job_title: Student Building Manager in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Flexible scheduling, relaxed work environment, and the ability to get to know a lot of people around campus.
cons: Job expectations are sometimes unclear and tasks are often trivial.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Great learning environment to teach. Wonderful students who want to learn. Faculty members always willing to help. Small class sizes
cons: There are not any cons that I have come across so far in my first few years at Webster.

job_title: in Kansas City, MO
pros: It is rewarding to work with students and help them obtain their goals.
cons:
Lack of business processes, poor work culture and employee engagement. Zero focus on talent development. 

Evaluative measures for employees are vague (same rating instrument used for all employees). No idea what performance measures will be weighted or how until being evaluated.

job_title: Coordinator in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Work life balance at Webster is outstanding. It is a flexible work environment and I trust the current administration.
cons: The university is not as progressive an many other liberal arts institutions. They are a bit slow to change and need to improve data and streamline communications.

job_title: Assistant to the Dean in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Great benefits, including free tuition for you and your family members.
cons: Inadequate compensation for the actual work done.

review_title: A hospital but decaying dead end.
job_title: Adjunct Associate Professor in Webster Groves, St. Louis, MO
pros: Great Atmosphere. Flexible Hours. Helpful Staff and Faculty.
cons: Supposedly a cash-strapped university. Horrible Pay. No benefits (aside from insufficient tuition remission for continuing Ed). Little to no opportunity for upward mobility.

job_title: Professor in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Excellent work-life balance, great opportunities for work-related travel, many pleasant and supportive colleagues, unique and likable student body.
cons: Too much focus on enrollments from administration, not enough on academic excellence.  Lack of follow-through on announced initiatives.

job_title: Adjunct Professor in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Well you do get some flexibility in terms of teaching methods as far as you follow the syllabus and teach the students what they need to know so that can be a little fun
cons: Not enough pay as adjunct compared to other universities. No benefits as adjunct

job_title: Adjunct Faculty in Saint Louis, MO
pros: I love helping students to increase knowledge! Webster campus in Columbia, SC is comfortable and conducive too safe learning!
cons: University needs to expand enrollment, hold faculty to accreditation standards of 4 hour per night, and work to integrate better in the Columbia SC community!

job_title: Computer Technician in Webster Groves, MO
pros: Relaxed environment, lots of extra paid days off when university is closed, tuition remission, good health insurance, no overtime or weekends
cons: very low pay compared to industry, no raises most years, very outdated infrastructure creates lots of pain points, very bureaucratic environment

job_title: Adjunct Professor in Prince Frederick, MD
pros: Webster University allows its instructors to freely adjust schedules and class times with students.
cons: The only con is that I can only teach one class per night, per term

review_title: Marred by political infighting and sexual harassment
job_title: Associate Professor in Saint Louis, MO
pros: The campus and students are great. I loved teaching here.
cons: Most academic departments are run by an old boys club. Sexual harassment and assault by senior male faculty against female students is rampant, and employees are discouraged from speaking up. Senior leadership ignore the problems. The culture and politics toxic.

job_title: Adjunct Professor in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: The faculty has the flexibility to include real life examples when teaching the academic theory.  The staff is exceptional interfacing with the students and faculty.
cons: After over 30 years at Webster, I have no complaints.

job_title: Assistant in Webster Groves, St. Louis, MO
pros: Amazing place to work for students. They are very friendly and helpful community. Always in need. Never felt it hard to work. There.
cons: Considerably, pay is a little less. But no cons as such based on my experience.

job_title: Assistant Director in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: Great benefits, comparable pay, treat employees like gold!
cons: No room for advancement unless willing to relocate.

job_title: MBA Tutor in Saint Charles, MO
pros: Active and energetic environment as I was dealing with people from the same age and working on the topics that i was enjoying a lot

job_title: Adjunct Faculty in San Antonio, TX

cons: Limited opportunities to teach. This may be due to more instructors hired in certain areas than student population can support.

job_title: Marketing/Communications Assistant in Indianapolis, IN

job_title: Adjunct Professor in Saint Louis, MO

job_title: Representative in Saint Louis, MO
